options.text: Formation of water from hydrogen and oxygen

questions.key_concept: Thermal decomposition reactions are typically endothermic.

questions.question_text: Photosynthesis is endothermic because it absorbs sunlight. A student argues it's not a chemical reaction because it happens in plants. Is the student correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, only lab reactions are chemical.

options.label: B
options.text: No, photosynthesis is a photochemical endothermic reaction where light energy is converted to chemical energy in glucose.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because plants are living, so it's a biological process, not chemical.

options.label: D
options.text: No, it's exothermic because plants release oxygen.

questions.key_concept: Biological processes are governed by chemistry; photosynthesis is a classic endochemical reaction.

questions.question_text: Why does the temperature drop when barium hydroxide octahydrate reacts with ammonium chloride?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an endothermic reaction absorbing heat from the surroundings, causing cooling.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an exothermic reaction that releases cold.

options.label: C
options.text: The reactants are naturally cold.

options.label: D
options.text: Because a gas is evolved which cools things.

questions.key_concept: Some double decomposition reactions are endothermic.

questions.question_text: How does the sustainability of an endothermic reaction differ from an exothermic one if the energy source is removed?

options.label: A
options.text: An endothermic reaction stops immediately when the energy supply (heat, light) is cut off. An exothermic reaction, once started, may sustain itself if it produces enough heat to maintain temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: Both stop immediately.

options.label: C
options.text: Endothermic reactions continue on their own, exothermic need continuous energy.

options.label: D
options.text: Energy supply has no effect on either.

questions.key_concept: Endothermic reactions require continuous energy input.

questions.question_text: Why is the formation of nitric oxide from nitrogen and oxygen (at ~3000°C) endothermic, and why is this high temperature needed?

options.label: A
options.text: The N≡N triple bond is very strong, requiring high energy input (high temperature) to break. The net process absorbs heat, making it endothermic.

options.label: B
options.text: Because oxygen is a gas.

options.label: C
options.text: To make the reaction exothermic.

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent the product from decomposing.

questions.key_concept: Strong bonds in reactants often lead to endothermic reactions requiring high activation energy.

concepts.concept_name: Photochemical and Electrochemical Reactions as Energy Changes

questions.question_text: What type of energy change is involved in a photochemical reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Absorption of light energy.

options.label: B
options.text: Release of electrical energy.

options.label: C
options.text: Release of sound energy.

options.label: D
options.text: Absorption of heat energy.

questions.key_concept: Photochemical reactions use light as the energy source.

questions.question_text: Which of these is both a photochemical and an endothermic reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Burning of magnesium

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Formation of ammonia

options.label: D
options.text: Electrolysis of water

questions.key_concept: Photosynthesis absorbs light energy (photochemical) and stores it as chemical energy (endothermic).

questions.question_text: A glow stick produces light when snapped. Is this a photochemical reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because light is produced.

options.label: B
options.text: No, it is a chemiluminescent reaction where chemical energy is converted to light. Photochemical reactions require light as an input to occur.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because it involves chemicals.

options.label: D
options.text: No, it's an electrical reaction.

questions.key_concept: Photochemical reactions are initiated by light, not just producing light.

questions.question_text: Electroplating uses an electrochemical reaction. What is the primary energy change involved?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrical energy is absorbed to cause a non-spontaneous chemical change (reduction of metal ions).

options.label: B
options.text: Light energy is absorbed to plate the metal.

options.label: C
options.text: Heat energy is released to melt the metal.

options.label: D
options.text: Sound energy is used to vibrate the solution.

questions.key_concept: Electroplating is an application of electrolysis (electrochemical).

questions.question_text: How do photochemical and electrochemical reactions compare as methods for driving non-spontaneous chemical changes?

options.label: A
options.text: Both use a specific form of energy (light or electricity) to provide activation energy or drive endothermic/redox reactions that wouldn't occur otherwise.

options.label: B
options.text: Photochemical reactions are always spontaneous, electrochemical are not.

options.label: C
options.text: Electrochemical reactions always produce gases, photochemical do not.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the same; light is a form of electricity.

questions.key_concept: Different energy forms can be used to force desired chemical transformations.

questions.question_text: Why is the decomposition of silver nitrate in sunlight considered a photochemical reaction, while its decomposition on strong heating is not?

options.label: A
options.text: Because sunlight (light energy) provides the specific activation for the photochemical pathway. Heat provides a different thermal activation pathway. The energy source defines the reaction type.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the products are different.

options.label: C
options.text: Because only the sunlight reaction is reversible.

options.label: D
options.text: Because silver nitrate only decomposes in light, not on heating.

questions.key_concept: The same compound can decompose via different mechanisms depending on the energy source.
